title: Abbreviation in Tribute Italic
content:
I've been using Tribute a lot lately and found a character I didn't recognize. It's in the Italic face and is the Nr. character. I assume it's an abbreviation for "number" (like No.), but I wanted to consult with the experts.

You know what happens when people assume. Thanks for taking a look.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Character.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417051054/http:/typophile.com/files/Character.png) | 14.96 KB |
author: Derek

comments.content:
"Nr." is the German equivalent of "No." in English. Tribute was designed by Frank Heine (a German). See this [wiki article about "No."](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417051054/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No.).

This is the second [German-specific](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417051054/http:/typophile.com/node/62727) font feature I've seen posted about today.

Awesome. Thanks for confirming.

I think it's a great alternate to the "No." I think "Nr." makes more sense, as there isn't an "o" in the word "number" (or nummer in the Germanic case).

Thanks again.
Well, in Spanish the word is “número”.
The "o" in "No." is from the ending _-o_ in Latin _numero_, meaning essentially "by number".
